title: How many oxygen atoms can a single hydrogen atom bond with? - Quora

response.answer_text: A hydrogen-bonded OH group can share the hydrogen between two oxygen atoms. The interatomic bond distance in water-ice is the same for both O-H bonds, so the H atom really is being shared between two oxygens. Atoms are not actually joined by straight lines as sketches of a molecule might show. The positive electric charge around a proton acts in all directions and will interact with any oxygen atom that can come within range. More that than 2 oxygen atoms can bond, protons are seriously small, and can fit in anywhere. Logical when you think about it. A proton in aqueous solution exists as a hydrate, i.e, H3O+, so oxygen can and does form trivalent compounds. Also possible are hygher hydrates, [H(H2O)n]+. A similar thing happens with sodium and posassium. Na2O seems reasonable (O2-, oxide) , but potassium more commonly forms KO2 (O^1/2-, superoxide) because K is much larger than O, and 2 potassiums cannot fit around an oxygen. This question relates to very basic chemistry, therefore a vary basic answer is required. A hydrogen atom has one outer electron and needs one more to complete it’s outer shell, ...therefore it can form only one covalent chemical bond, …therefore it has a valency of 1 (one), …therefore it can combine with only one atom of any element, oxygen included. Oxygen has six outer electrons and needs 2 electrons to complete its outer shell, hence it has a valency of 2 (two), …therefore oxygen can combine (bond with) up to two other atoms. Therefore when hydrogen and oxygen combine to form a covalent molecule, it is usually two hydrogen atoms with one oxygen hence H2O (water)… H-O-H = water TWO hydrogens can also combine with TWO oxygen atoms if the oxygens also form a bond with each other to make H2O2 (hydrogen peroxide)… H-O-O-H = hydrogen peroxide (The relationship between outer electrons, valency and types of bond formed are different questions.)
